Award.AwardTitle: Investigations in Elementary Particle Physics and Particle Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides three-year continued support for the experimental particle physics and astroparticle physics programs at Michigan State University. The intellectual merit deals with the completion of the final chapter of the 1967 Standard Model and its necessary evolution through physics studies at D0 and CDF at the Tevatron at Fermilab, ATLAS at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland, the NuMI Off-axis neutrino Appearance (NOvA) experiment at Fermilab and Ash River, MN, and the High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) experiment at the Gamma Ray Observatory at the Sierra Negra in Mexico. The primary research focus is new experiments: ATLAS, HAWC, and NOvA with a selective physics program at D0 and CDF to the completion of the Tevatron program. The broader impacts of this work include the opportunity to bring these front-line research questions into classrooms and to the public at large through lectures and interactive video presentations. In addition, the group engages more than a dozen graduate students and a number of undergraduates into the labs at MSU, Fermilab, and CERN providing unique experiences for students who are often not physics majors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The standard model of particle physics acquired its single missing piece in 2012. Long a target of confirmation, the discovery of the Higgs Boson crowns the standard model the most precise scientific model in history and serves as the launching pad for the next steps in understanding the deepest secrets that nature only reluctantly uncovers. We participated directly and indirectly in the discovery…a process in a large experiment like ATLAS that’s distributed among the physicists who directly analyzed the data, but also those of us who built the detector, coded the trigger, determined the backgrounds, and created the national computing centers necessary to bring all of our calculations together. All of these were Michigan State University physicists' contributions.

The next steps will be built on the historic conceptual realizations that the standard model gives us. First, the universe not only respects symmetries, but quite possibly is built around them. Before the confirmation of this nearly 50 year old model, mathematical symmetry was largely a technique to organize the pieces - the particles - in the world. But now we know that the symmetries are dynamical and prescriptive instructions: identify the symmetry and you’re led to the not only the forces at play and the messenger particles that transmit them, but also how those “vector bosons” interact with the fundamental particles. Symmetries no longer organize, they account for the players and the rules of the game. Next, the Higgs boson's discovery was the link between what we can measure directly and the existence of the Higgs Field, the more fundamental substance that interacts with elementary particles and endows them with mass. Mass, we now know, was born soon after the Big Bang and is not an inherent property of matter. Finally, the standard model hinted at another example of unity in physical theories and this confirmation continues that trend toward a potentially ultimate single force of nature.

Our work at the LHC and the tevatron was motivated by these realizations that the stakes are high. We’re not only investigating our current neighborhood, but also recreating the epoch after the big bang at which those crucial symmetries were changing with the cooling of the cauldron that would have been the first instants of the universe.

The standard model is also perplexing in a variety of ways. First, the mass generation for fermions implied by the Higgs Field is only understood for electrically charged fermions. The neutral fermions - the ghostly neutrinos - are still an object of fevered research. How they receive their tiny masses and whether that mechanism is the same, just similar, or entirely different from the "Higgs mechanism" of their charged cousins is a critical question, both inherently and cosmologically. We are pursuing this accelerating front-line of the overall particle physics battle with neutrino oscillation research at Fermilab. Second, the mass value of the Higgs boson itself is suggestive of some other set of particles and symmetries. It's too small to be the logical last step, hence the 2012 discovery is indeed a launching pad to new, but now uncharted waters.

Finally, the sky is full of surprises, not the least of which are high energy gamma ray emissions and other astrophysical phenomena, at their heart, particle physics matters of great interest. Michigan State has branched out into those areas as well, completing our engagement in all three particle physics "frontiers": energy, intensity, and cosmic. 

This work doesn't happen without small armies of graduate students, technical staff, and post doctoral researchers. The experience gained by these scientists and engineers is a stimulant to the technical workforce in the United States since most do not continue research in basic particle physics, but rather take their unique skills into the private economy, increasingly eager for young scientists who can work in large groups, confront enormous data sets in sophisticated and proper ways, and experienced in attacking technical challenges which don't rely on previous practice - the most important skill learned in fundamental scientific research.
